document.docAuthor: Breitkreuz, Laura C. V., Ohl, Michael & Engel, Michael S.
document.docTitle: Arpactophilus fwai Breitkreuz, Ohl & Engel, 2016, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A review of the New Caledonian Arpactophilus (Hymenoptera: Crabronidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the New Caledonian Arpactophilus (Hymenoptera: Crabronidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis.
Arpactophilus fwai
is the only New Caledonian species in the genus that has the combination of an entirely yellow clypeus, with a shallow V-shaped incision (
Fig. 55
), a head that is about as long as wide, two submarginal cells in the forewing and a black or brown mesoscutellum (in most specimens), and the meso- and metasoma ventrally black or dark brown (
Fig. 56
).
Description. FEMALE: Total length 3.8–4.4 mm , mean = 4.0 mm; forewing length 2.3–2.6 mm , mean = 2.5 mm .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 53–58. Facial views and lateral habitus of ♀ holotypes (except for
Arpactophilus gressitti Bohart
) of species of
Arpactophilus Smith.
53.
A. futuna
sp. nov.
, facial view; 54.

, lateral habitus; 55.

sp. nov.
, facial view; 56.

, lateral habitus; 57.

, facial view; 58.
A. gressitti
, lateral habitus.

subSubSection.paragraph: MALE: Difference from female aside from genitalic structures: some specimens with light brown marking on mesoscutellum. Metasomal sternum VIII neither broadened nor narrowed.

Remarks.
Arpactophilus fwai
is most similar to
A. yuanga
in body size and coloration, but they may be easily distinguished by the coloration of the clypeus which is entirely yellow in the former (
Fig. 55
) basally brown to black in the latter (
Fig. 111
). Very few specimens have a faint yellow coloration of the mesoscutellum (similar to
Fig. 19
, but less bright), which leads to the split of this species in the key. These specimens are easily distinguished from the other species with a yellow mesoscutellum. In comparison to
A. paici
and
A. scutellaris
the meso- and metasoma are not yellow ventrally (
Fig. 56
). The fully yellow clypeus of the species (
Fig. 55
) distinguishes
A. fwai
from
A. merle
and
A. nere
, which have a medially brown clypeus ( Figs. 71 , 77 ).

Etymology. The specific epithet is taken from the name Fwâi , one of the New Caledonian native languages. It is treated as a noun in apposition.
